section.title: Casper
section.para: Rejected because it looks similar to Embedded JS: Allows a JSP like syntax using Javascript snippets, and because it seems to be too much hobby-ish (No community or enterprise behind it).

section.title: Hamlets
section.para: Java based, parses HTML in a SAX fashion and throws events on unknown tag that you have to implement in Java. Originally written at IBM.
Rejected as it seems to complex and oriented towards Java devs instead of web developers.

section.title: Jasper
section.para: Rejected because it's poorly documented and supported. It's also unclear if it's just a template system or an application framework (it seems to deal itself with request parameters).

section.title: jsTenjin
section.para: Javascript based, syntax similar to Embedded JS but too complex: Every single line has to start and end with delimiters <?js ...?>.

section.title: YAJET
section.para: Javascript based, but with a counter-intuitive syntax. Moreover there seems to be no community at all: A single message in their Google Groups dated from Oct. 2010.

section.title: Non mature enough
section.para:
Some template engine I've found didn't seem really mature or well supported:
GvTags: Groovy based
Too young, lacks features, and no release since Feb. 2008.
Jin Template: HTML + Java or PHP
Uses pure HTML files as template and embeds directives in HTML comments which makes it a bit hard to read.
Not very documented.
TrimPath Templates: Javascript
Looked interesting at first sight with nice feature and easy to extend, but unfortunately seems abandoned: The last release is from 2007, the last "news" on the page is from 2005, and the Google group is completely spamed and doesn't contain any real message.
